results.title: Animals of the Arctic
results.creator_credit: Stephen Maslowski, Karl Maslowski and Centron Films
results.brief_description: This film introduces students to the wide variety of wildlife that roams the plains and seashores of the Arctic. It shows how the animals and birds have adapted to their environment. Photography: Karl and Stephen Maslowski. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Animal Crackers
results.brief_description: This is one of the Marx Brothers’ funniest films, with Groucho starring as the big, wild, game hunter causing more delirium in high society than in the jungle! A painting is stolen in a high society home, and the Marx Brothers are there to lend their confusing hand to solve the crime.

results.title: Angus lost
results.creator_credit: Gary Templeton, John Sturner, Firehouse Productions and Evergreen Productions
results.brief_description: Angus is a very curious, clever Scottish terrier, whose curiosity gets him into a number of close scrapes. This is a live-action, non-verbal adaptation of Marjorie Flack’s classic book and is sure to delight audiences both young and old.

results.title: Angus
results.creator_credit: Andy Thomson, Michael Scott, William Canning and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film portrait of Angus Mowat, with commentary by his son, author Farley Mowat. At 76, Angus still shows an enviable capacity for life, turning his hand to things that the leisure of retirement now makes possible. One of these is the rebuilding of an old fishing boat, converting it to sail. This is a picture of a man who has reached his later years with no slackening of interest in life, who finds a good and constant companion in nature, and contentment in the quiet isolation of his cabin by the shore.

results.title: Angotee: story of an eskimo boy
results.creator_credit: Douglas Wilkinson, Michael Spencer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The time is 1953 and the place is the eastern Arctic. Beginning with a scene in an igloo showing the birth of Angotee to Atootoo, wife of the hunter Koonuk, this film follows the events of a man’s growth from birth to maturity. During babyhood Angotee is secure in the protection of his mother. His childhood is free and happy as he plays games invented out of the skills he will need as a man. During adolescence he accompanies his father on the hunt and enters the company of men where he shoots his first seal. The story ends as Angotee leaves the parental igloo to set up his own abode as a family man and a hunter of the great snow-swept barrens. Awards: Durban; Trento; Toronto.

results.title: Angkor, the lost city
results.creator_credit: Roger Blais and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Angkor - a whole metropolis of palaces and temples recovered from the jungle which hid them for centuries until discovered in 1860 by a French naturalist. Monuments, picture tapestries in stone and Angkor Vat, a mile square temple of grey sandstone which no other church has rivalled in size, reveal the glories of the past empire of the Khmers, ancestors of the Cambodians.

results.title: Angel food
results.creator_credit: Julia Bourke, Paul Fletcher, Anne Shenfield, Robert Stephenson and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Animated film that charts the short-lived adventures of an intrepid strawberry as it evades a variety of kitchen hazards - including vicious utensils, distraction by a Busby Berkeley-style fruit mambo, and a seductive but ultimately deadly pot of melted chocolate - to fulfill its quest to sit atop a decadent whipped cream and meringue dessert. “A glossy tale with a sticky end.”

results.title: Angels with dirty faces
results.creator_credit: Michael Curtiz and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Despite his success in musicals and comedies throughout his career, James Cagney will be remembered best for his tough guys roles in “White heat”, “Public enemy” and “Angels with dirty faces”. Boyhood friends Rocky (Cagney) and Jerry (Pat O’Brien) grew up in opposite directions; one a hoodlum, the other a priest overseeing a group of orphans in the neighbourhood where he and Rocky grew up. These youngsters idolise Rocky and soon they’re breaking the law in an effort to win his respect. Fearing for the boys’ future, Father Connelly takes a stand against Rocky’s underworld ways, leading to one of the classic James Cagney shoot outs. The ending of this picture transcends its gangster-film surface and elevates it to that of meaningful social commentary, wherein Rocky has to face the true meaning of courage. The case also includes a young Humphrey Bogart as Rocky’s two-faced lawyer.

results.title: And then there were none = Ten little indians
results.creator_credit: Rene Clair, Harry M Popkin and Popular Pictures
results.brief_description: Ten strangers, each with a criminal past, are invited to attend a party on desolate island off the English coast at the request of a mysterious host, Mr Owen. As the group settle into their sojourn, it gradually dawns on them that they have been gathered on the island to be murdered, one by one, as penance for their crimes. It seems that guests are being murdered according the nursery rhyme, “Ten little Indians”, but even knowing what murder is coming next can’t prevent it- the surviving Indians must find the mysterious Mr Owen, masquerading as one of the guests, to stop the deadly cat and mouse game. Cast includes Walter Huston, Louise Hayward, Roland Young and Judith Anderson. Based on the novel by Agatha Christie.

results.title: Angels over Broadway
results.creator_credit: Lee Garmes, Ben Hecht and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Angels over Broadway is a stylish looking black and white crime drama which takes place on one rainy night in New York. In a nightclub on Broadway called the Pigeon Club a suicidal embezzler arrives, wet and hopeless. He is mistaken as a rich country hick ripe for hustling. An alcoholic playwright becomes involved and the plot unfolds. This film, written and directed by Ben Hecht who is famous for witty and sharp dialogue, is well acted with an impressive cast. The hustler and would-be gangster, Douglas Fairbanks Jr. is teamed with the good-time girl Rita Hayworth. With a fine script of ironic and poetic dialogue this dark drama is compelling. The noir themes of espionage, gambling, suicide and bad guys turning good are present in this shadowy, cynical and articulate film. With an Academy Award nomination for Best Original Screenplay this is a fine film located in the world of loners, hustlers and has-beens. Cast includes Thomas Mitchell and John Qualen.
